questions.text: Identify the chest x-ray finding shown below. ( FMGE Jan 2024 )
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Lung collapse

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ The opacity and associated signs of volume loss indicate that part of the lung has collapsed, likely due to an obstruction or compression of the airways.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis according to the given image? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.correct_answer: B. Pseudoaneurysm of internal carotid artery
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Pseudoaneurysm of internal carotid artery

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The given image shows a digital subtraction angiography of ICA and it shows an outpouching of the contrast suggestive of a pseudoaneurysm of the internal carotid artery as marked by the arrow.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A . C arotid-cavernous fistula (CCF) is the result of an abnormal vascular connection between the internal carotid artery (ICA) and the cavernous sinus . Pulsatile proptosis of eye would be the pathognomic clinical finding. DSA would reveal enlarged draining superior ophthalmic vein.
  • • Option A
  • • C
  • • arotid-cavernous fistula (CCF)
  • • Option C. Tumor blush of angiofibroma would show feeder vessels from internal maxillary artery of ECA.
  • • Option
  • • C. Tumor blush of angiofibroma
  • • Option D. Extensive head and neck hemangioma would show multiple tortuous vessels supplying a mass which is not seen here.
  • • Option D. Extensive head and neck hemangioma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A pseudoaneurysm of the internal carotid artery is characterized by an outpouching of contrast material in angiographic studies, as seen in the provided DSA image. This finding is distinct from other vascular abnormalities such as carotid-cavernous fistulas, angiofibromas, or hemangiomas.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with severe back pain, vomiting, and hypotension. CT findings are given below. What is the diagnosis?(AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Renal angiomyolipoma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The CT image shows a left renal lesion with negative /low attenuation (black in color) that indicate fatty tissue. This is consistent with renal angiomyolipoma. Clinical findings of severe back pain, vomiting, and hypotension and hematoma around the renal mass are suggestive of rupture. This is known as Wunderlich syndrome .
  • • Wunderlich syndrome
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Renal cysts are homogeneous hypodense lesions.
  • • Option A.
  • • Renal cysts
  • • Option B. Renal cell carcinoma will appear heterogeneous and hypervacular with areas of necrosis.
  • • Option B.
  • • Renal cell carcinoma
  • • Option C. Para pelvic cyst are simple renal cysts that plunge into the renal sinus from the adjacent renal parenchyma. A parapelvic cyst at times may cause compression of the pelvicalyceal system resulting in hydronephrosis.
  • • Option C. Para pelvic cyst

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Renal angiomyolipoma is typically composed of fat, muscle, and blood vessels and appears as a low-attenuation mass on CT scans. When associated with symptoms like severe pain and hypotension, it raises concerns for potential hemorrhage or rupture, emphasizing the need for prompt evaluation and management.

questions.text: A 39-year-old male patient presented with complaints of fever and cough. His chest radiograph shows air bronchogram sign. The probable diagnosis is:(AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Consolidation

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The patient complaining of fever and cough with positive air bronchogram sign on chest x-ray suggests lobar consolidation which is most commonly due to Pneumococcal pneumonia.
  • • Air bronchogram refers to the phenomenon of air-filled bronchi (dark) being made visible by the opacification of surrounding alveoli (grey/white). It is almost always caused by a pathologic airspace/alveolar process, in which something other than air fills the alveoli.
  • • Air bronchogram
  • • The causes of air bronchogram are as follows:
  • • Pulmonary consolidation Pulmonary Edema : especially with alveolar edema Neoplasms: bronchioloalveolar carcinoma ; pulmonary lymphoma
  • • Pulmonary consolidation
  • • Pulmonary Edema : especially with alveolar edema
  • • Neoplasms: bronchioloalveolar carcinoma ; pulmonary lymphoma
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Pleural effusion: Would typically show blunting of the costophrenic angles and a fluid level on the chest X-ray, not associated with air bronchograms.
  • • Option A. Pleural effusion:
  • • Option B. Hilar lymphadenopathy: Presents as enlarged hilar shadows on X-ray, which do not include the air bronchogram sign.
  • • Option B. Hilar lymphadenopathy:
  • • Option D. Bronchiectasis: Characterized by permanent dilation of parts of the airways of the lung; air bronchograms can be present but are more commonly associated with acute infections or consolidations.
  • • Option D. Bronchiectasis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The air bronchogram sign on a chest X-ray, indicative of the presence of air within the bronchi surrounded by opacified alveoli, is a classic feature of pulmonary consolidation, most commonly seen in pneumococcal pneumonia.

questions.text: Personal monitoring of radiation is done by:(NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. TLD badge

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Personal monitoring of radiation is done by a TLD badge.
  • • Given to radiation personnel for its usage. Personnel dosimeter. Thermoluminescent 3 monthly [sent for measurement in India] Made up of CaSO 4 : Dysprosium [LiF can also be used] Worn below the lead apron at the level of the chest
  • • Given to radiation personnel for its usage.
  • • Personnel dosimeter.
  • • Thermoluminescent
  • • 3 monthly [sent for measurement in India]
  • • Made up of CaSO 4 : Dysprosium [LiF can also be used]
  • • Worn below the lead apron at the level of the chest
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Collimators: Used in radiographic devices to narrow the beam of radiation to limit exposure and improve image quality, but not for monitoring radiation exposure.
  • • Option A. Collimators:
  • • Option C. Linear accelerator: A device primarily used in cancer treatment to deliver high-energy x-rays or electrons to the region of the patient's tumor. It is not a monitoring device.
  • • Option C. Linear accelerator:
  • • Option D. Grid: Used in radiographic imaging to improve image contrast by absorbing scattered radiation, not for measuring radiation exposure.
  • • Option D. Grid:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A TLD badge is a critical tool for radiation safety, allowing for accurate monitoring and measurement of radiation exposure over time to ensure that radiation workers do not exceed safe exposure limits. This is crucial in maintaining occupational health standards in radiologically active environments.

questions.text: A patient reports a painless mass that has been gradually increasing in size. An X-ray has been performed. What is the diagnosis?(FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Osteochondroma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Osteochondroma is a benign condition that typically presents as a painless, slowly growing mass near the growth plates of long bones. It's identified on X-rays by its distinct protrusion with a cartilaginous cap.
  • ➤ Osteochondroma is a benign condition that typically presents as a painless, slowly growing mass near the growth plates of long bones. It's identified on X-rays by its distinct protrusion with a cartilaginous cap.

questions.text: The X Ray of the skull as shown in the image given below is seen in: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Hyperparathyroidism

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Radiological skull features of hyperparathyroidism are:
  • ➤ Radiological skull features of hyperparathyroidism are:

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding CORDS? (INICET NOV 2021)

options.label: C
options.text: Pleural thickening is typical of COVID-19

options.label: D
options.text: Lobar consolidation is typical of COVID-19

questions.correct_answer: B. CORADS-5 is typical of COVID-19
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • CORADS-COVID-19 Reporting and Data System
  • • CO-RADS is a categorical assessment scale used to evaluate pulmonary involvement of COVID-19 on chest CT scans. Each category reflects the level of suspicion of COVID-19.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. CO-RADS-0: This category indicates that the CT examination is insufficient for assessment, not that the lungs are normal, which is a common misunderstanding.
  • • Option A. CO-RADS-0:
  • • Option C. Pleural thickening: While pleural thickening can occur in COVID-19, it is not typical or diagnostic of the disease. COVID-19 primarily affects the parenchyma of the lungs rather than the pleura.
  • • Option C. Pleural thickening:
  • • Option D. Lobar consolidation: Though lobar consolidation may be present in severe cases of COVID-19, it is not typical of the disease, as COVID-19 more frequently presents with peripheral ground-glass opacities.
  • • Option D. Lobar consolidation:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ COVID-19 Reporting and Data System (CO-RADS) is a categorical assessment for pulmonary involvement of COVID-19 on chest CT.

questions.text: Which of the following investigations is shown in the radiograph? ( NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Barium meal

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The given image is a barium meal. This study is used to examine the stomach and proximal duodenum.
  • • Visual Cues: The image shows the distribution of barium within the stomach, outlining its contours and revealing its internal structure, which is typical in a barium meal examination.
  • • Visual Cues:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Barium Swallow: This study primarily evaluates the esophagus and does not extend into the stomach. The radiograph showing the stomach filled with barium indicates that the procedure goes beyond just a barium swallow.
  • • Option A. Barium Swallow:
  • • Option C. Barium Meal Follow Through: This investigation involves not only the stomach but also a sequential imaging of the small intestine as the barium passes through. The specific image provided does not show barium beyond the proximal duodenum, which is typical in a simple barium meal.
  • • Option C. Barium Meal Follow Through:
  • • Option D. Barium Enema: This procedure is used to visualize the large intestine (colon) and rectum using barium introduced via the rectum. The provided image showing the stomach filled with barium clearly indicates that it's not a barium enema.
  • • Option D. Barium Enema:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Identify the marked ligament? (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) PCL

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The marked ligament in the MRI scan is the PCL (Posterior Cruciate Ligament) . This identification is supported by the ligament's location and trajectory as depicted in the image.
  • ➤ PCL (Posterior Cruciate Ligament)

questions.text: Identify the marked structure. (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Internal capsule

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The internal capsule is a key white matter structure in the brain, crucial for transmitting motor and sensory information between the cerebral cortex and the spinal cord. It is located between the thalamus and the basal ganglia

questions.text: A 35-year-old male with motor traffic accident with BP 90/60mm Hg. On examination, he was stable with GCS 15/15. The pupil was reactive to light. Tenderness and bruising over the left lower chest wall with petechia were seen. What is the next step? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. eFAST

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The next step in the evaluation of a trauma patient with the given findings is the Extended Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma (eFAST). This non-invasive imaging technique is crucial for rapidly identifying free fluid and organ injuries in the abdomen, as well as potential pneumothorax or hemothorax, which are critical in trauma cases. eFAST is used to quickly assess both stable and unstable patients following blunt abdominal trauma, providing immediate information that can dictate further management steps.
  • • both stable and unstable patients
  • • Details:
  • • Details:
  • • eFAST Role: This ultrasound examination checks for free intraperitoneal or pericardial fluid and can evaluate the integrity of the pleural spaces.
  • • eFAST Role:
  • • Stability: Despite the patient's low blood pressure, he is neurologically intact (GCS 15/15) and responsive, which allows for an ultrasound examination before more invasive procedures are considered.
  • • Stability:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Exploratory laparotomy: Generally reserved for patients showing signs of hemodynamic instability after eFAST or when eFAST is positive for intra-abdominal injury needing surgical intervention.
  • • Option A. Exploratory laparotomy:
  • • Option B. Intubation: Might be necessary if respiratory status worsens or if advanced airway management is required, but the patient’s current stable neurological status does not immediately warrant this.
  • • Option B. Intubation:
  • • Option D. CECT (Contrast Enhanced CT Scan): Used after eFAST if the patient remains hemodynamically stable and further detailed evaluation of internal injuries is necessary.
  • • Option D. CECT (Contrast Enhanced CT Scan):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis based on the given image? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Chronic osteomyelitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chronic osteomyelitis is characterized by periosteal thickening, sclerosis, and central lucency within the bone, which are key diagnostic features visible on imaging.

questions.text: Whole- body CT scan protocol for a trauma patient includes all, except? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) CT limbs

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • CT Limbs is not included in the whole-body CT of a trauma patient.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. CT Head: Non-contrast CT (NCCT) of the head to check for any intracranial hemorrhages or fractures.
  • • Option A. CT Head:
  • • Option B. CT Cervical Spine: NCCT of the cervical spine to assess for any fractures or dislocations that may compromise the spinal cord.
  • • Option B. CT Cervical Spine:
  • • Option D. CT Abdomen: Contrast-enhanced CT of the torso, including the abdomen and pelvis, to evaluate for internal injuries such as organ lacerations, bleeding, or other trauma-related abnormalities.
  • • Option D. CT Abdomen:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Whole-body CT or trauma CT includes:
  • ➤ NCCT head NCCT C-spine Contrast-enhanced CT of torso
  • ➤ NCCT head
  • ➤ NCCT C-spine
  • ➤ Contrast-enhanced CT of torso

questions.text: Based on the provided X-ray, what is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Hollow viscus perforation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of air under the right diaphragm on an erect chest X-ray is a strong indicator of a hollow viscus perforation and is considered a surgical emergency

questions.text: Identify the procedure? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Myelography

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The procedure shows contrast within the subarachnoid space in myelography.
  • • Expansion of the contrast-filled space in myelography is seen in intradural extramedullary tumors. In myelography, contrast is injected into the CS space, and if a tumor is present in the intradural extramedullary space, it causes the CS space on that side to widen. Neurofibroma and meningioma are two examples of such lesions and on myelography with the contrast column, these lesions will also have a meniscus-like appearance.
  • • Expansion of the contrast-filled space in myelography is seen in intradural extramedullary tumors.
  • • In myelography, contrast is injected into the CS space, and if a tumor is present in the intradural extramedullary space, it causes the CS space on that side to widen.
  • • Neurofibroma and meningioma are two examples of such lesions and on myelography with the contrast column, these lesions will also have a meniscus-like appearance.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Angiography: Involves the injection of contrast material into blood vessels and is used primarily to examine vascular structures, not visible in this image.
  • • Option A. Angiography:
  • • Option C. DEXA: Stands for Dual Energy X-ray Absorptiometry, a method used to measure bone density, not applicable here.
  • • Option C. DEXA:
  • • Option D. Projectional radiography: Refers to standard X-ray imaging without contrast enhancement, whereas this procedure clearly involves contrast material within the spinal canal.
  • • Option D. Projectional radiography:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Myelography is an essential diagnostic tool for visualizing the spinal subarachnoid space and identifying pathologies that may impact the spinal cord and nerve roots, providing crucial information that cannot be obtained through standard X-rays alone.

References:

  • ↳ Reference - Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 822

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Anencephaly is diagnosed by the absence of cranial bones and brain tissue on ultrasound, often accompanied by the "frog eye sign."

questions.text: Which of the following isn't considered a benefit of USG compared to Mammography? (INICET MAY 2023)

options.label: A
options.text: Can be used for screening mammographically undetectable or clinically non palpable breast mass

options.label: B
options.text: Useful in young females with dense breast

options.label: C
options.text: Differentiates between solid and Cystic lesions in the Breast

questions.correct_answer: A. Can be used for screening mammographically undetectable or clinically non palpable breast mass
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Can be used for screening mammographically undetectable clinically non palpable breast mass

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ultrasound should not be considered a standalone screening tool for non-palpable breast masses or those not detected by mammography. However, it is invaluable in specific scenarios such as evaluating women with dense breasts, distinguishing between cystic and solid breast lesions, and facilitating guided biopsies.

questions.text: A 51-year-old man complains of abdominal pain and blood-stained stools. The barium study of his intestines shows the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Intussusception

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The given clinical scenario and the barium study are characteristic of intussusception.
  • • INTUSSCUSCPTION
  • • INTUSSCUSCPTION
  • • Age: 6-8 months most common Can be seen in adults due to a lead point like polyp or carcinoma. C/F: Painful red currant jelly stools. Mc type: Ileocolic Intussusception. Initial: USG
  • • Age: 6-8 months most common
  • • Age:
  • • Can be seen in adults due to a lead point like polyp or carcinoma.
  • • C/F: Painful red currant jelly stools.
  • • C/F:
  • • Mc type: Ileocolic Intussusception.
  • • Mc type:
  • • Initial: USG
  • • Initial:
  • • Target/ Donut/ Sandwich/ Pseudo-kidney sign
  • • Target/ Donut/ Sandwich/ Pseudo-kidney sign
  • • IOC/Gold standard: Barium most commonly done/Air/Saline enema.
  • • IOC/Gold standard:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Volvulus: Typically presents with a massively dilated loop of bowel and may show a "whirl sign" on CT rather than the findings seen on this barium study.
  • • Option A. Volvulus:
  • • Option C. Diverticulitis: Would show inflamed and sometimes perforated diverticula; barium would outline these pouches, not the pattern seen here.
  • • Option C. Diverticulitis:
  • • Option D. Ulcerative colitis: Chronic inflammatory condition of the colon, typically demonstrates continuous colonic involvement with loss of haustra, mucosal edema, and ulceration.
  • • Option D. Ulcerative colitis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Intussusception in adults requires prompt diagnosis and often surgical intervention, especially when associated with a pathological lead point. The barium study is crucial for diagnosis, showing specific patterns like the "target" sign that aid in identifying this condition.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male came with complaints of acute abdominal pain. A plain X-ray abdomen erect was taken which is shown below. What is likely diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Pneumoperitoneum

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The presence of subdiaphragmatic free gas in the right upper quadrant is clearly visible in the X-ray above. This is an indication of pneumoperitoneum.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Subdiaphragmatic abscess: Typically presents with localized fluid collections that may contain gas produced by bacteria, but the extensive free air pattern as seen in this X-ray is more characteristic of pneumoperitoneum.
  • • Option A. Subdiaphragmatic abscess:
  • • Option C. Pneumopericardium: Involves air in the pericardial cavity, not typically visible as free air under the diaphragm.
  • • Option C. Pneumopericardium:
  • • Option D. Intestinal obstruction: May show air-fluid levels and dilated bowel loops, but the clear presence of free air under the diaphragm is distinctly indicative of pneumoperitoneum rather than an obstruction alone.
  • • Option D. Intestinal obstruction:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ MOST SENSITIVE X RAY: CXR-PA erect
  • ➤ MOST SENSITIVE X RAY: CXR-PA erect
  • ➤ Air under the diaphragm-Right
  • ➤ MOST SENSITIVE Ix: CECT with oral contrast NEXT STEP: Resuscitation with iv fluids, Exploratory laparotomy
  • ➤ MOST SENSITIVE Ix: CECT with oral contrast
  • ➤ MOST SENSITIVE Ix: CECT with oral contrast
  • ➤ NEXT STEP: Resuscitation with iv fluids, Exploratory laparotomy
  • ➤ NEXT STEP: Resuscitation with iv fluids, Exploratory laparotomy

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with a severe headache is scheduled to undergo a CT scan. During history taking, which of the following will you definitely ask for before the commencement of the scan? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) LMP

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The most important information to obtain during a history in a 28-year-old woman of reproductive age who has been referred for a CT scan is the last menstrual period (LMP). Since it is imperative to rule out pregnancy before taking a CT scan, last menstrual period is the most appropriate answer to this question.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Use of cochlear implant: While important in MRI to prevent damage to the implant from the magnetic field, it is not typically a concern in CT scans which use X-rays.
  • • Option A. Use of cochlear implant:
  • • Option C. History of fall: Although relevant to the medical history, it is not critical specifically before a CT scan unless symptoms suggest complications that a CT scan could exacerbate.
  • • Option C. History of fall:
  • • Option D. History of hypertension: Important in overall patient assessment but does not directly influence the decision to perform a CT scan as critically as confirming pregnancy status does.
  • • Option D. History of hypertension:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Inquiring about the Last Menstrual Period (LMP) is essential for any woman of childbearing age before undergoing diagnostic procedures involving radiation, such as a CT scan, to avoid potential harm to an unborn baby.

questions.text: Egg shell calcification is seen in all the following, except? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Metastatic lymph node

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • A ring of calcification at the periphery of a lymph node is known as eggshell calcification.
  • • While calcifications can occur in metastatic nodes, they usually do not form the classic eggshell pattern. Instead, calcifications in metastatic nodes are often more irregular or diffusely distributed.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Silicosis: This condition, often seen in individuals exposed to silica dust, can lead to eggshell calcification of the lymph nodes due to chronic inflammation and fibrosis.
  • • Option A. Silicosis:
  • • Option B. Sarcoidosis: Another granulomatous disease that can lead to eggshell calcification in lymph nodes as part of its systemic manifestation affecting the lungs and lymphatic system.
  • • Option B. Sarcoidosis:
  • • Option C. Post-radiation therapy lymph nodes: Radiation can induce changes in lymph node structure including calcifications, commonly in a peripheral pattern, as a late sequela of treatment.
  • • Option C. Post-radiation therapy lymph nodes:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Eggshell calcification is a specific radiologic sign associated with certain granulomatous diseases and post-treatment changes but is not commonly seen in metastatic lymph nodes. It may be seen in:
  • ➤ Silicosis Sarcoidosis post-radiation therapy in lymph nodes post-ATT in lymph nodes in TB
  • ➤ Silicosis
  • ➤ Sarcoidosis
  • ➤ post-radiation therapy in lymph nodes
  • ➤ post-ATT in lymph nodes in TB

questions.text: A 75 year old diabetic patient presents with acute right flank pain, chills, and rigors. The following investigation has been conducted. What is the presumptive diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Emphysematous Cholecystitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ Emphysematous cholecystitis is most commonly seen in diabetic patients and shows presence of gas around the gallbladder area on the X-ray, indicated by the dark patches resembling air pockets.
  • ➤ Emphysematous cholecystitis is most commonly seen in diabetic patients and shows presence of gas around the gallbladder area on the X-ray, indicated by the dark patches resembling air pockets.

questions.text: During rounds, your senior was discussing the given image. The following is an image of which of the following investigations? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. CT scan

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The above given image is a CT scan image since the bone can be identified as a high-density structure which appears white.
  • • CT scan is an imaging modality which uses X-rays for cross sectional images of the body and the density of the tissue through which this x-ray beam passes is measured from the calculation of attenuation coefficient.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Contrast Dye study: While contrast may be used in CT scans, the term "contrast dye study" alone does not specifically indicate a CT scan.
  • • Option A. Contrast Dye study:
  • • Option B. X-ray: Typically provides two-dimensional imaging and lacks the cross-sectional detail shown in these images.
  • • Option B. X-ray:
  • • Option C. D Angiography: Focuses on blood vessels using contrast material and typically does not provide detailed images of other anatomical structures as seen in these scans.
  • • Option C. D Angiography:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ CT scans are invaluable in medical imaging for providing detailed cross-sectional views of internal structures, utilizing X-ray technology to distinguish between different tissue densities, evident from the white appearance of bone and detailed soft tissue visualization in the images.

questions.text: An elderly lady presents with abdominal pain and distension. She has a history of chronic constipation. What is the most likely diagnosis?(INICET MAY 2022)

options.label: B
options.text: Large bowel obstruction due to fecolith

options.label: D
options.text: Small bowel obstruction due to bowel perforation

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Sigmoid volvulus

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The abdominal X-ray shows a characteristic "coffee bean sign," which is indicative of a sigmoid volvulus. This radiological sign represents a massively distended sigmoid colon twisted on itself, resembling a bent tube or coffee bean. This condition is more common in elderly individuals, particularly those with a history of chronic constipation, due to the increased bowel length and mobility, combined with decreased bowel tone. Sigmoid volvulus can lead to severe abdominal pain and distension, as observed in this patient.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Large bowel obstruction due to fecolith: Typically presents with signs of obstruction but lacks the specific 'coffee bean' appearance associated with volvulus.
  • • Option B. Large bowel obstruction due to fecolith:
  • • Option C. Cecal volvulus: Would show a single dilated loop of bowel, often with haustrations, and generally appears in a different location and shape compared to the sigmoid volvulus.
  • • Option C. Cecal volvulus:
  • • Option D. Small bowel obstruction due to bowel perforation: Would likely show signs of free air under the diaphragm on an X-ray, which is not visible in the provided image.
  • • Option D. Small bowel obstruction due to bowel perforation:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 6-week-old child was brought to the emergency department with complaints of recurrent projectile vomiting. USG of the child is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) CHPS (Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ CHPS is characterized by projectile, non-bilious vomiting in an infant around 6 weeks of age, and is best diagnosed with an ultrasound showing thickened pyloric muscle and a narrowed pyloric canal.

questions.text: Double bleb sign seen in early pregnancy is due to? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.correct_answer: C. Yolk sac and amniotic sac
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Yolk sac and amniotic sac

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The double bleb sign is due to the yolk sac and amniotic sac.
  • • On USG, gestational sac contains the yolk sac and amniotic sac which appear as two small bubbles known as the double bleb sign.
  • • It is seen at 7.5 – 8 weeks.
  • • Do not confuse with Double decidual sign
  • • Double decidual sign
  • • Double decidual sign – true gestational sac surrounded by two layers – decidua capsularis and decidua parietalis with fluid collection in between.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Twin pregnancy: This would involve two separate gestational sacs or distinct embryonic structures in a single sac, not the double bleb sign of a single gestational sac.
  • • Option A. Twin pregnancy:
  • • Option B. Amnion and chorion: These are two layers surrounding the embryo, but the double bleb sign specifically refers to the early visualization of the yolk sac and amniotic sac.
  • • Option B. Amnion and chorion:
  • • Option D. Heterotopic pregnancy: Involves simultaneous intrauterine and extrauterine pregnancies. This would not specifically relate to the double bleb sign, which is a normal ultrasound finding in a single intrauterine pregnancy.
  • • Option D. Heterotopic pregnancy:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The double bleb sign is a normal ultrasound finding in early pregnancy, showing the presence of both the yolk sac and the amniotic sac within the gestational sac, important for confirming a normal early intrauterine pregnancy.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis based on the X-ray? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Patella fracture

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A patella fracture can be identified on an X-ray by a distinct fracture line through the patella, differentiating it from other conditions like hemarthrosis, bipartite patella, and ligament injuries.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presenting with recurrent respiratory infections. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) CPAM

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ CPAM is characterized by multiple cystic, air-filled spaces in the lung and is a congenital lesion that often presents with recurrent respiratory infections.

questions.text: What is the best imaging study for diagnosis of cerebral infarct?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Diffuse weighted MRI

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Diffusion-weighted MRI is the most sensitive investigation for diagnosis of cerebral ischemia. It is particularly useful for identifying acute ischemic changes in the brain due to its ability to detect diffusion restriction of water molecules in the brain tissue.
  • • Diffusion-weighted MRI is the most sensitive investigation
  • • Diffusion restriction: hyperintense on DWI and hypointense on ADC.
  • • Diffusion restriction:
  • • Diffusion restriction is seen with: Acute stroke Hypercellular tumors Abscess Epidermoid cyst Keratin-Craniopharyngioma/ Cholesteatoma
  • • Diffusion restriction is seen with: Acute stroke Hypercellular tumors Abscess Epidermoid cyst Keratin-Craniopharyngioma/ Cholesteatoma
  • • Acute stroke Hypercellular tumors Abscess Epidermoid cyst Keratin-Craniopharyngioma/ Cholesteatoma
  • • Acute stroke
  • • Hypercellular tumors
  • • Abscess
  • • Epidermoid cyst
  • • Keratin-Craniopharyngioma/ Cholesteatoma
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. FLAIR MRI: Fluid-Attenuated Inversion Recovery (FLAIR) MRI is useful for identifying older infarcts and chronic changes but is less sensitive in the acute phase of a stroke.
  • • Option A. FLAIR MRI:
  • • Option B. Non-contrast CT: While commonly used for initial assessment due to its availability and speed, it is less sensitive in the early stages of a stroke, often not showing changes until several hours post-onset.
  • • Option B. Non-contrast CT:
  • • Option D. СECT (Contrast-Enhanced CT): Typically used to assess for complications or other causes of symptoms but not as sensitive as DWI for early detection of cerebral infarcts.
  • • Option D. СECT (Contrast-Enhanced CT):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Diffusion-weighted MRI is the optimal choice for early detection of cerebral infarcts, making it an indispensable tool in acute stroke management. Its ability to show diffusion restriction provides critical information that can influence therapeutic decisions.

questions.text: A 38-year-old female presented to the emergency department with the sudden onset of severe epigastric pain, she had a history of heart burn and dyspeptic symptoms for past 10 years. On physical exam, she had a temperature of 101.44° F, a pulse of 115bpm and a blood pressure of 125/72mmHg. Abdomen was tender & rigid. What is the likely diagnosis?(AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Pneumoperitoneum

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The presence of free gas under the right diaphragm in the X-ray. This is suggestive of pneumoperitoneum.
  • • C/F: Acute abdominal pain, rigidity, tenderness, guarding MOST SENSITIVE X RAY: CXR-PA erect
  • • C/F: Acute abdominal pain, rigidity, tenderness, guarding
  • • MOST SENSITIVE X RAY: CXR-PA erect
  • • MOST SENSITIVE X RAY: CXR-PA erect
  • • Air under the diaphragm-Right
  • • MOST SENSITIVE Ix: CECT with oral contrast NEXT STEP: Resuscitation with iv fluids, Exploratory laparotomy
  • • MOST SENSITIVE Ix: CECT with oral contrast
  • • MOST SENSITIVE Ix: CECT with oral contrast
  • • NEXT STEP: Resuscitation with iv fluids, Exploratory laparotomy
  • • NEXT STEP: Resuscitation with iv fluids, Exploratory laparotomy
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Pneumothorax which represents air in the pleural space, collapsed lung and sometimes mediastinal shift to the opposite side. Presentation is variable and may range from no symptoms to severe dyspnea with tachycardia and hypotension.
  • • Option A. Pneumothorax
  • • Option C. Subdiaphragmatic abscess , there is an infradiaphragmatic localized collection of fluid with gas bubbles or gas-fluid level which has an enhancing wall. It is often combined with elevation of the hemidiaphragm and a pleural effusion.
  • • Option C. Subdiaphragmatic abscess
  • • Option D. Intestinal obstruction on abdominal radiographs show dilated loops of small bowel proximal to the obstruction with visible valvulae conniventes.
  • • Option D. Intestinal obstruction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pneumoperitoneum is a critical diagnosis identified by the presence of free air under the diaphragm on X-ray, indicative of gastrointestinal perforation, requiring immediate surgical intervention.

questions.text: Identify the imaging modality given below? (INCET NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) USG

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The given image is suggestive of USG of the neck.
  • • The thyroid gland, muscles, blood vessels, bony structures or cartilages, and nerves are all visible on a sonographic examination of the neck.
  • • On USG, normal thyroid appears homogeneously hyperechoic with a uniform echotexture. Large blood vessels (the common carotid artery and, more laterally, the internal jugular vein) can be seen laterally to the thyroid.
  • • USG is the radiological IOC to evaluate thyroid nodules.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Fluoroscopy: Primarily used for real-time imaging of moving body structures using X-rays, which is not indicated by the type of static image and detail shown.
  • • Option B. Fluoroscopy:
  • • Option C. X-Ray: Typically shows denser tissues like bones and lacks the detailed soft tissue contrast visible in this ultrasound image.
  • • Option C. X-Ray:
  • • Option D. MRI: Provides high-resolution images of internal structures using magnetic fields and radio waves, typically not showing the real-time flow or specific echogenic properties visible in ultrasound images.
  • • Option
  • • D. MRI:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ultrasound (USG) is the imaging modality of choice for evaluating the thyroid and other neck structures due to its ability to provide detailed images of soft tissue structures without exposure to ionizing radiation. It is particularly useful for assessing the thyroid gland, including the evaluation of nodules and vascular structures.

questions.text: Which of the following findings are seen in a high-resolution CT scan of fungal pneumonia?(INICET MAY 2022)

options.label: D
options.text: Cavitatory lesions with surrounding ground glass opacities

questions.correct_answer: D. Cavitatory lesions with surrounding ground glass opacities
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Cavitatory lesions with surrounding ground glass opacities

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Invasive aspergillosis
  • • HALO SIGN – Multiple nodules with central solid part and haziness around the lesion Seen in immunocompromised individuals with febrile neutropenia DOC – voriconazole
  • • HALO SIGN – Multiple nodules with central solid part and haziness around the lesion
  • • Seen in immunocompromised individuals with febrile neutropenia
  • • DOC – voriconazole
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Kerley lines: Commonly associated with interstitial edema and pulmonary congestion, not specifically fungal pneumonia.
  • • Option A. Kerley lines: Commonly
  • • Option B. Hilar lymph nodes: While enlargement can be seen in various conditions, it is not a specific finding for fungal pneumonia.
  • • Option B. Hilar lymph nodes:
  • • Option C. Pleural effusion: Although it may be present in various lung infections and conditions, it is not characteristic of fungal infections like invasive aspergillosis.
  • • Option C. Pleural effusion:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cavitatory lesions with surrounding ground glass opacities on a high-resolution CT scan are indicative of fungal infections like invasive aspergillosis, especially in immunocompromised patients. Recognition of these signs is crucial for the timely initiation of appropriate antifungal therapy.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis based on the given image? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Aberrant right subclavian artery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ An aberrant right subclavian artery is an anatomical variant where the artery arises as the fourth branch of the aortic arch and courses posterior to the esophagus, often leading to dysphagia lusoria due to esophageal compression.

questions.text: A child with acute lymphoblastic leukemia undergoes prophylactic irradiation prior to autologous hematopoietic stem cell transplantation. Which of the following will be the least affected? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Neurons

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Neurons (Central nervous system) are the least affected by irradiation among the options given, due to their highly differentiated and non-dividing nature.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option. A. Spermatogonia : These are germ cells that continually divide and are highly sensitive to radiation, which can lead to infertility.
  • • Option. A. Spermatogonia
  • • Option. B. Intestinal epithelial cells : These cells have a high turnover rate, making them very sensitive to radiation, which can result in gastrointestinal toxicity.
  • • Option. B. Intestinal epithelial cells
  • • Option. D. Bone marrow/erythroid precursor cells : These cells are among the most sensitive to radiation due to their role in rapidly producing new blood cells, leading to potential marrow suppression.
  • • Option. D. Bone marrow/erythroid precursor cells

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient presented with a headache and altered sensorium. MRI was performed which revealed multiple rings enhancing lesions. MR spectroscopy showed a prominent lipid-lactate peak. What is the likely diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Tuberculoma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The MRI findings of multiple ring-enhancing lesions in conjunction with a prominent lipid-lactate peak on MR spectroscopy are characteristic of tuberculoma. Tuberculomas are focal infections that typically present as ring-enhancing lesions in the brain, often around the brainstem, and can conglomerate. The lipid-lactate peak on MR spectroscopy is indicative of necrosis, which is a feature seen in tuberculomas (and also in conditions like toxoplasmosis). The combination of imaging and spectroscopy findings helps distinguish tuberculomas from other similar conditions.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Neurocysticercosis (NCC): Typically presents with cystic lesions in the brain, which may show ring enhancement but does not characteristically show a lipid-lactate peak on MR spectroscopy.
  • • Option A. Neurocysticercosis (NCC):
  • • Option C. Progressive Multifocal Leukoencephalopathy (PML ): Generally shows non-enhancing, white matter lesions on MRI without a significant lipid-lactate peak on MR spectroscopy.
  • • Option C. Progressive Multifocal Leukoencephalopathy (PML
  • • Option D. Cryptococcomas: These fungal infections might present similarly on imaging but do not typically show a lipid-lactate peak on MR spectroscopy.
  • • Option D. Cryptococcomas:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tuberculomas:
  • ➤ Tuberculomas:
  • ➤ Tuberculomas- foci of infection and show ring enhancing lesion More common around brainstem Show conglomeration MR spectroscopy shows lipid lactate peak – necrosis (also seen in toxoplasmosis)
  • ➤ Tuberculomas- foci of infection and show ring enhancing lesion
  • ➤ More common around brainstem
  • ➤ Show conglomeration
  • ➤ MR spectroscopy shows lipid lactate peak – necrosis (also seen in toxoplasmosis)
  • ➤ No prominent metabolite is seen in NCC/PML/Cryptococcoses.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman landed up in AIIMS emergency after a road traffic accident with GCS of 3. She was intubated and sent for NCCT which was found to be normal. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Diffuse axonal injury

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The given clinical scenario of the patient who had an RTA presents with an abnormal clinical manifestation and no imaging abnormality suggests diffuse axonal injury.
  • • Initial investigation for DAI→ NCCT: Normal or tiny microbleeds
  • • IOC for DAI → MRI
  • • Sequence of MRI best: SWI/ Gradient MR: Shows blooming suggestive of axonal shearing
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Post-concussion syndrome: This generally follows a mild traumatic brain injury, not severe cases presenting with a GCS of 3 and typically involves symptoms like headaches, dizziness, and cognitive difficulties developing after the injury.
  • • Option B. Post-concussion syndrome:
  • • Option C. Extradural hemorrhage: This condition would usually present with a focal mass effect on an NCCT, which was not noted in this case.
  • • Option C. Extradural hemorrhage:
  • • Option D. Herniation of brain: Brain herniation typically shows significant structural displacement on NCCT, which was reported as normal in this patient.
  • • Option D. Herniation of brain:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Diffuse axonal injury is a significant concern in patients with severe trauma and low GCS, especially when initial NCCT scans do not reveal significant abnormalities. MRI, particularly with SWI or gradient MR sequences, is crucial for proper diagnosis due to its sensitivity to microbleeds and axonal injuries.

questions.text: A patient presents with abdominal pain and distension. An abdominal X-ray was done, as shown below. Identify the bowel segment involved? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Jejunum

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The given clinical scenario and X-ray are suggestive of intestinal obstruction where the involved segment is the jejunum. The obstructed bowel loops are centrally located and have valvulae conniventes (complete mucosal folds), indicating jejunal involvement.
  • • obstructed bowel loops are centrally located and have valvulae conniventes
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option. B. Ileum : Typically, ileal loops are located more peripherally and may show less prominent valvulae conniventes.
  • • Option. B. Ileum
  • • Option. C. Duodenum : Not usually seen as prominently distended in obstructions due to its fixed retroperitoneal location and smaller length.
  • • Option. C. Duodenum
  • • Option. D. Transverse colon : Would generally show haustrations (sacculations) rather than valvulae conniventes, and distension would be more peripherally located.
  • • Option. D. Transverse colon

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 22-year-old male was brought to the emergency room following a road traffic accident. On examination, his GCS was E2M2V3. He had no fractures and no hydrocephalus or raised intracranial pressure. Non-contrast CT was performed and was found to be normal. The likely diagnosis is? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A Diffuse axonal injury

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The given clinical scenario of the patient who had an RTA presents with an abnormal clinical manifestation and no imaging abnormality suggests diffuse axonal injury.
  • • C/F: High energy trauma (road traffic accident) + Low GCS score / comatose
  • • C/F:
  • • Initial investigation for DAI→ NCCT: Normal or tiny microbleeds
  • • IOC for DAI → MRI
  • • IOC for DAI
  • • Sequence of MRI best: SWI/ Gradient MR: Shows blooming suggestive of axonal shearing
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Post-concussion syndrome: Patients with post-concussion syndrome have mild traumatic brain injury. It does not present with a severe clinical status as seen in this patient.
  • • Option B. Post-concussion syndrome:
  • • Option C. Extra Dural hemorrhage: Extradural hemorrhage results secondary to trauma to head. The bleeding is usually arterial and blood collects between outer dura and inner table of the skull. It can very well be visualized on CT.
  • • Option C. Extra Dural hemorrhage:
  • • Option D. Post-concussion syndrome: A cerebral herniation is a shift of cerebral tissue in an adjacent space. Intracranial brain herniation can be classified into 3 types - subfalcine, trans tentorial and tonsillar. A distinct clinical picture can be produced as a result of compression of neurovascular structures by the herniating part. CT is the imaging modality of choice because it can be done rapidly.
  • • Option D. Post-concussion syndrome:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of road traffic accidents where a patient presents with a significant neurological deficit and a normal initial CT scan, diffuse axonal injury should be considered. An MRI with specific sequences is required to confirm the diagnosis and understand the extent of injury.

questions.text: Which of the following statements are false regarding X Rays? (AIIMS MAY 2018)

options.label: A
options.text: Loss of soft tissue planes is the earliest X-ray change of infection

options.label: B
options.text: Glass pieces can be seen as radiopaque in X-ray images

options.label: C
options.text: Cartilage is not visualized on X-ray.

options.label: D
options.text: Live bone is more radio-opaque than dead bone on X- Ray

questions.correct_answer: D. Live bone is more radio-opaque than dead bone on X- Ray
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Live bone is more radio-opaque than dead bone on X- Ray images.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • On X-ray imaging, dead bones are whiter (more radio-opaque) than live bone due to absence of bone resorption activity as vascular demineralization is lost. This is known as sequestrum.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Loss of soft tissue planes is the earliest X-ray change of infection: This statement is true. The loss of definition of soft tissue planes due to swelling or fluid accumulation is often the earliest radiographic sign of infection, typically appearing within 24-48 hours after disease onset.
  • • Option A. Loss of soft tissue planes is the earliest X-ray change of infection:
  • • Option B. Glass pieces can be seen as radiopaque on X-ray images: This is true. Glass, especially if it contains lead, shows up as radiopaque on X-rays, making it visible.
  • • Option B. Glass pieces can be seen as radiopaque on X-ray images:
  • • Option C. Cartilage is not visualized on X-ray: This is true. Cartilage itself does not appear on X-rays because it does not absorb X-rays well; the space where cartilage is located appears radiolucent, which is often perceived as joint space.
  • • Option C. Cartilage is not visualized on X-ray:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ On X-ray imaging, dead bone appears more radio-opaque than live bone due to the lack of resorption activity. Understanding these differences is crucial for correctly interpreting radiologic findings related to bone vitality and infection.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents with complaints of abdominal pain. Further workup showed elevated PTH levels and renal calculi. Which investigation should be done next? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Tc-99m sestamibi scan

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a patient with elevated PTH levels and clinical features suggestive of primary hyperparathyroidism, such as renal calculi, the Tc-99m sestamibi scan is the preferred investigation to localize a parathyroid adenoma.

questions.text: What is the most sensitive investigation for parathyroid tumor imaging? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Tc Sestamibi SPECT

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • For the imaging of parathyroid tumors, particularly in the context of hyperparathyroidism, several modalities can be employed. Each has its strengths and particular clinical situations where it might be the preferred choice.
  • • Tc Sestamibi SPECT (Single Photon Emission Computed Tomography technique also utilizes Technetium-99m sestamibi but combines it with CT imaging to provide three-dimensional imaging. This makes SPECT more sensitive than a plain sestamibi scan for locating parathyroid tumors, especially when they are ectopic or embedded deep within the neck or chest.
  • • Tc Sestamibi SPECT (Single Photon Emission Computed Tomography
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Tc Sestamibi Scan : This is a nuclear medicine scan that uses a small amount of a radioactive compound , typically Technetium-99m sestamibi, which is absorbed by active parathyroid tissue more than normal tissue. While sensitive, it provides a two-dimensional view which can sometimes make precise localization of smaller or deeper tumors challenging.
  • • Option A. Tc Sestamibi Scan
  • • Option C. USG (Ultrasound): Ultrasound is useful for imaging the parathyroid glands due to its non-invasive nature and ability to detect lesions in real-time. It is particularly effective for glands located in typical positions near the thyroid. However, its effectiveness diminishes for ectopic glands or in obese patients where acoustic windows may be poor.
  • • Option C. USG (Ultrasound):
  • • Option D. MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging): MRI can provide detailed images and is useful in complex cases, such as when other imaging modalities fail or in surgical planning. However, its sensitivity is generally lower than Sestamibi SPECT for detecting parathyroid adenomas, and it is less commonly used primarily due to higher costs and limited availability.
  • • Option D. MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Tc Sestamibi SPECT is generally considered the most sensitive imaging modality for detecting parathyroid tumors, particularly because it offers three-dimensional localization capabilities that can greatly assist surgeons in planning minimally invasive surgery.

questions.text: Identify the site marked in given barium follow-through of small intestine.(FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Jejunum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The jejunum can be identified in imaging by the presence of valvulae conniventes creating a feathery appearance, distinguishing it from the ileum and colon.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient has come with sudden onset of chest pain and his CT scan shows the following picture. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Aortic dissection

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ AORTIC DISSECTION
  • ➤ AORTIC DISSECTION
  • ➤ Risk factor – Hypertension (MC), connective tissue disorder – Marfan’s syndrome Clinical features – Acute chest pain, radiating to back IOC in unstable patients - TEE IOC in stable patients - CT angiography
  • ➤ Risk factor – Hypertension (MC), connective tissue disorder – Marfan’s syndrome
  • ➤ Risk factor –
  • ➤ Clinical features – Acute chest pain, radiating to back
  • ➤ Clinical features –
  • ➤ IOC in unstable patients - TEE
  • ➤ TEE
  • ➤ IOC in stable patients - CT angiography
  • ➤ CT angiography
  • ➤ Stanford classification
  • ➤ Stanford classification
  • ➤ Ascending is involved – Urgent surgical intervention B – Ascending not involved – Medical management – IV esmolol
  • ➤ Ascending is involved – Urgent surgical intervention
  • ➤ B – Ascending not involved – Medical management – IV esmolol

questions.text: Identify the image. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Fluoroscopy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fluoroscopy is a dynamic X-ray imaging technique used to visualize the motion of the pharynx and esophagus during swallowing. It provides real-time assessment, unlike a static barium swallow.

questions.text: Identify the structures marked. (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.  D) 1- liver 2-spleen 3-pancreas

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Other Option:
  • • Other Option:
  • • Option D: 1- liver, 2- spleen, 3- pancreas : Correct based on organ anatomy and typical CT appearance.
  • • Option D: 1- liver, 2- spleen, 3- pancreas

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ Accurate identification of abdominal organs on imaging studies like CT scans is essential for diagnosing diseases, planning surgeries, and tracking treatment progress.

questions.text: A patient presents in OPD with a history of fever and cough for 5 days. On auscultation, crepts were heard on right side. Chest X-ray is given below. Mark the correct finding in this case? (NEET PG 2023)

options.label: A
options.text: Apical segment of Right lower lobe consolidation

options.label: C
options.text: Posterior segment of right lower lobe consolidation

questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Right middle lobe consolidation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Right middle lobe consolidation is suggested by the obscuration of the right heart border and the specific location of opacity on the chest X-ray, aligned with the patient's clinical presentation of respiratory symptoms. This finding is crucial for diagnosing the specific location of pneumonia, guiding appropriate treatment.

questions.text: A patient complains of difficulty breathing and fatigue. On examination, distended neck veins and muffled heart sounds were found. X-ray is shown below. Identify the condition.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Cardiac tamponade

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ Cardiac tamponade is a life-threatening emergency which looks like ‘ water bottle heat’ on x-ray and that requires immediate intervention, typically pericardiocentesis, to relieve the pressure on the heart. Any patient presenting with the classic triad of tamponade and signs consistent on imaging should be managed with urgent care to stabilize the condition and prevent cardiac arrest.

questions.text: A 45-year-old banker presented with vague abdominal pain. On US, he was found to have a renal mass lesion. CECT was done, as shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Renal angiomyolipoma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The CT image presented here shows well-circumscribed lesions with low attenuation (black in color) that indicate fatty tissue. The presence of macroscopic fat is strongly suggestive angiomyolipoma. The presence of macroscopic fat within the lesion, which results in negative Hounsfield units on CT, is a key diagnostic feature of angiomyolipoma.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. RCC (Renal Cell Carcinoma): Typically appears as a solid mass that may be hypervascular and can show necrosis but does not characteristically contain macroscopic fat.
  • • Option A. RCC (Renal Cell Carcinoma):
  • • Option B. Renal oncocytoma: Usually presents as a well-circumscribed, solid mass with a central scar, which is not visible in this image.
  • • Option B. Renal oncocytoma:
  • • Option D. Renal cyst: Would appear as a fluid-filled structure without solid components, typically with very clear borders and no internal complexity or enhancement.
  • • Option D. Renal cyst:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Cervical Rib

Explanation:

  • • Explanation :
  • • Cervical Ribs
  • • Cervical Ribs
  • • Cervical ribs are supernumerary or accessory ribs arising from the seventh cervical vertebra.
  • • C/F: Usually asymptomatic, they are the most important anatomic rib variant clinically, because they can cause thoracic outlet syndrome by compression of the brachial plexus or subclavian vessels.
  • • Thoracic outlet syndrome: Most commonly-C8, T1 roots compression
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Costochondritis: Involves inflammation of the rib cage's cartilage, particularly where the upper ribs attach to the sternum, an area not visible as an anomaly on X-rays.
  • • Option A. Costochondritis:
  • • Option C. Rib Fracture 2nd / 3rd: Would show discontinuity or displacement of the rib bones, which is not evident here.
  • • Option C. Rib Fracture 2nd / 3rd:
  • • Option D. C5/C6 Spondylolisthesis: Pertains to the displacement of one of the spinal vertebra in relation to another, typically seen in the neck's vertebral column, not visible on this thoracic X-ray.
  • • Option D. C5/C6 Spondylolisthesis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ Cervical ribs are supernumerary ribs that can cause complications such as thoracic outlet syndrome due to their position and potential to compress nearby nerves and blood vessels.

questions.text: What is the best contrast agent for the diagnosis of esophageal perforation? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Iohexol

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Identify the fracture site in the X-ray shown below. (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 4th, 5th, 6th rib

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When identifying rib fractures on a chest X-ray, start counting from the first rib, which is located just beneath the clavicle, and follow downward. Note the curvature of the ribs: anterior ribs curve downward and outward, while posterior ribs curve upward. This method helps in accurately locating and identifying the specific ribs involved in fractures or other abnormalities.

questions.text: A woman has been diagnosed with endometrial carcinoma is undergoing radiotherapy. Choose the correct statement? (NEET PG 2023)

options.label: A
options.text: Intensity is inversely proportional to the square of the distance from the source

options.label: B
options.text: Small blood vessels are most radioresistant

options.label: C
options.text: Rapidly proliferating cells are most radioresistant

options.label: D
options.text: Small intestinal mucosa is most radio-resistant

questions.correct_answer: A. Intensity is inversely proportional to the square of the distance from the source
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Intensity is inversely proportional to the square of the distance from the source

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Inverse Square Law is critical to understanding radiation dosage and safety in radiotherapy, ensuring that radiation exposure is managed correctly to maximize the therapeutic effect while minimizing harm to healthy tissues. This principle helps in planning and delivering radiation treatments effectively.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with cancer is undergoing radiotherapy. She is given a dose of 1.8 to 2 Gy daily for five days a week, for a total treatment duration of 6 to 8 weeks. What among the following explains this type of radiotherapy? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Conventional Fractionation radiotherapy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Conventional Fractionation radiotherapy involves delivering 1.8 to 2 Gy per day, five days a week, for 6 to 8 weeks, allowing for normal tissue recovery between treatments.

questions.text: A child presented with a history of road traffic accident. The axial CT image of the child is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Extradural hemorrhage

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The CT image shows a right-sided hyperdense area indicative of an acute extradural hemorrhage (EDH). Extradural hemorrhages typically result from high-energy trauma, such as a road traffic accident, and are often arterial in origin, frequently involving the middle meningeal artery (MMA). The classic biconvex or "lens-shaped" appearance, as observed, does not cross sutures but may cross the midline, distinguishing it from other types of hemorrhages.
  • • Right sided hyperdense acute EDH is shown in the NCCT
  • • Right sided hyperdense acute EDH is shown in the NCCT
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Subdural Hemorrhage: Typically presents with a crescentic or "banana-shaped" appearance, crosses sutures, and involves bridging veins, usually from lower energy trauma or trivial injuries, which is not compatible with the findings on this CT.
  • • Option B. Subdural Hemorrhage:
  • • Option C. Subarachnoid Hemorrhage: Involves bleeding into the subarachnoid space, generally producing a diffuse or layered appearance in the CT, which is not evident here.
  • • Option C. Subarachnoid Hemorrhage:
  • • Option D. Intraventricular Hemorrhage: Results in blood within the ventricular system, showing up as hyperdense within the ventricles, not applicable to this case.
  • • Option D. Intraventricular Hemorrhage:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: During evaluation of PUO, a patient's chest X-ray is as seen below. What is your diagnosis?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Miliary tuberculosis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The given chest X-ray depicts miliary tuberculosis.
  • • Miliary tuberculosis:
  • • Miliary tuberculosis:
  • • Bilateral randomly distributed nodules on HRCT. Hematogenous spread.
  • • Bilateral randomly distributed nodules on HRCT.
  • • Hematogenous spread.
  • • Miliary pattern D/D:
  • • Miliary pattern D/D:
  • • Healed varicella TPE/ Loeffler’s syndrome Hemosiderosis Silicosis
  • • Healed varicella
  • • TPE/ Loeffler’s syndrome
  • • Hemosiderosis
  • • Silicosis
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Pulmonary edema: Typically presents with bilateral opacities, predominantly in the perihilar regions, and may show Kerley B lines, none of which are visible in this X-ray.
  • • Option B. Pulmonary edema:
  • • Option C. Necrobiotic nodules: Commonly associated with conditions like rheumatoid arthritis, presenting as larger, well-defined nodules, which is not the case here.
  • • Option C. Necrobiotic nodules:
  • • Option D. Tuberculoma: Typically appears as a solitary, well-defined round lesion, often with a calcified center, not the diffuse pattern observed here.
  • • Option D. Tuberculoma:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Miliary tuberculosis is characterized by fine, diffuse nodules throughout the lungs, resulting from widespread dissemination of the tuberculosis bacteria. This is a serious condition requiring immediate medical attention and treatment.
  • ➤ Miliary tuberculosis is characterized by fine, diffuse nodules throughout the lungs, resulting from widespread dissemination of the tuberculosis bacteria. This is a serious condition requiring immediate medical attention and treatment.

questions.text: A patient presented with the X-ray. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Miliary TB

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Miliary TB presents with numerous small, uniformly distributed nodules on a chest X-ray, resembling millet seeds. This pattern is a hallmark of disseminated tuberculosis.

questions.text: A young male is complaining of pain, and the image shows a lesion in the diaphysis. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Osteoid osteoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ When encountering a patient with localized bone pain and a small radiolucent lesion in the cortex of the bone, consider osteoid osteoma in the differential diagnosis. Early and accurate diagnosis can lead to effective treatment, primarily with NSAIDs or surgical excision, providing significant symptom relief.
  • ➤ When encountering a patient with localized bone pain and a small radiolucent lesion in the cortex of the bone, consider osteoid osteoma in the differential diagnosis. Early and accurate diagnosis can lead to effective treatment, primarily with NSAIDs or surgical excision, providing significant symptom relief.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is the Banana sign on USG associated with? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Spina bifida

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The "Banana sign" on ultrasound is specifically associated with spina bifida and represents the abnormal shape of the cerebellar vermis. It is a critical ultrasound finding suggestive of spina bifida and should be carefully evaluated alongside other signs such as the "Lemon sign," which depicts an abnormal skull shape resembling a lemon, also indicative of neural tube defects like spina bifida.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with bitemporal hemianopia. CT is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Craniopharyngioma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • A calcified lesion in the suprasellar region suggests craniopharyngioma . It is derived from Rathke's pouch.
  • • calcified lesion in the suprasellar region
  • • suggests craniopharyngioma
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A: Pituitary adenomas are seen in the sellar region in adults. Macroadenomas are seen as snowman or figure of eight appearance.
  • • Option A:
  • • Macroadenomas are seen as snowman or figure of eight appearance.
  • • Option B: Meningioma is a supratentorial tumor, mainly in the parasagittal region. A classical Dural tail is seen.
  • • Option B:
  • • Dural tail
  • • Option D : Oligodendroglioma is exclusively found in the cerebral hemispheres, most commonly in the frontal lobes. Up to 90% of oligodendrogliomas contain visible calcification on CT .
  • • Option D
  • • calcification on CT

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Craniopharyngioma should be considered in pediatric patients presenting with visual disturbances and evidence of a calcified mass in the suprasellar region on imaging. This diagnosis is important due to the potential impact on the optic pathways and pituitary gland function, requiring careful management.
